Remote Plasma ALD of Platinum and Platinum Oxide Films
Materials Innovation Institute M2i, 2600 GA Delft, The Netherlands
Eindhoven University of Technology, 5600 MB Eindhoven, The Netherlands
Philips Research, 5656 AE Eindhoven, The Netherlands

2009 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/1.3125876] All rights reserved.
Manuscript submitted February 20, 2009; revised manuscript received April 7, 2009. Published April 27, 2009.

When deposited with the precise thickness control and high conformality of atomic layer deposition (ALD), platinum films have a large variety of potential applications in microelectronics and energy technologies due to their chemical stability, catalytic activity, and excellent electronic properties.1- 7 While being less investigated, platinum oxide is of interest because of its optical properties and because
8- 10 In the research efforts toward the applications of these films deposited by ALD, nucleation properties, material quality, and process temperature window are of key importance.
Few Pt ALD processes have been reported, of which the thermal ALD process using (methylcyclopentadienyl)trimethylplatinum
gas described by Aaltonen et al. has become the most adopted.2,3 This process relies on the dissociative chemisorption of
surface for oxidative decomposition of the precursor ligands.11,12 For
only one ALD process has been reported, to the best of our knowledge.13
films were obtained from the combination of
in the small temperature window of
In this article, ALD processes are reported for

plasma, O radicals are created, providing atomic O to the surface directly from the gas phase, enhancing oxygen chemisorption and oxidation.14 The growth and nucleation properties, material properties, and substrate- temperature dependence of the
process are investigated for remote plasma ALD and benchmarked against the thermal ALD of Pt.

films were deposited in the open- load ALD- I setup described extensively in Ref. 15. In short, a deposition chamber was connected to an inductively coupled plasma source and a pump unit through gate valves. The pump unit consisted of a turbo molecular pump and a rotary pump reaching a base pressure of

precursor dosing with the bottom valve closed (no pumping) to maximize precursor usage. After the precursor exposure the reaction products were pumped out by opening the bottom valve to the turbo pump. For thermal ALD the second half- cycle
For the remote plasma process the

In situ spectroscopic ellipsometry (SE) with a J. A. Woollam, Inc. M2000U
ellipsometer was employed to determine the thickness and the dielectric function of the films during the ALD process. After deposition the optical range was extended to

using ex situ variable- angle measurements with a J. A. Woollam, Inc. M2000D.15 Electrical resistivity was measured by a four- point probe (FPP), whereas the atomic composition and mass density of the films were determined from Rutherford backscattering spectrometry (RBS) using
ions. The microstructure of the films was studied using X- ray diffraction (XRD) with a Philips X'Pert MPD diffractometer equipped with a

radiation). Additionally, the thickness and mass density were determined by X- ray reflectometry (XRR) measurements on a Bruker D8 Advance X- ray diffractometer. The surface roughness of the films was determined by atomic force microscopy (AFM) using an NT- MDT Solver P47 SPM.

or native oxide for the conditions employed. Pt growth on these substrates could only be achieved by using a higher

it is concluded that growth per cycle is constant after the first 50 cycles. On the

Material properties.- As shown in Table I both the remote plasma and thermal ALD process result in very similar material properties for the
films. In both cases high density
films were deposited. The density and resistivity for these
thick films are close to the bulk values of
, and they are similar to the values reported for thermal ALD of
. The O and C contents remain below the RBS detection limit
and grazing incidence XRD spectra (Fig. 3) revealed a cubic phase composition for both the thermal and remote plasma ALD
films. The relatively high intensity of the (220) peak indicates that the
crystallites have a preferred orientation with their (111) lattice planes parallel to the sample surface as also reported for the thermal ALD process. The remote plasma ALD

film, which is only slightly thicker than the thermal ALD film, shows much stronger diffraction peaks, indicating a higher crystallinity. Both processes resulted in smooth films and had generally lower root- mean- square roughness values (

). Because island growth is known to promote surface roughening, the fast nucleation and, consequently, more pronounced layer- by- layer growth can be related to the lower surface roughness obtained for the remote plasma ALD process.
The platinum oxide has a lower density and is slightly overstoichiometric
. The resistivity is very high as it is above the detection limit of the FPP
was reported most probably due to a lower O content

Temperature dependence.- Figure 4 shows the growth per cycle for the three processes over a wide temperature range. The thermal ALD Pt process has a temperature window starting at
The fact that the growth per cycle is reduced at lower substrate temperatures is not yet understood.21 From surface science studies, it can be inferred that the dissociative chemisorption of
should not be the limiting factor.12 On the other hand, the remote plasma ALD process which uses atomic oxygen from the gas phase has a higher growth rate than the thermal process at
found for this temperature, however, suggests incomplete removal of O and C impurities from the material. The poorer material properties could be overcome by an
